Posts.Content: My previous doc used to do just that. He'd always go through all the results and then made a point of asking me if I had any questions or issues. I miss that but hope my new one does the same.
Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Just had an MRI on my prostate and found that it was 61.5 cc in volume. Now my urologist says my prostate is about 50 grams. One is volume and one is weight, right? Is there a conversion between volume and weight somewhere? I'm guessing the MRI is going to be a bit more accurate than my urologist's fuzzy ultrasound system.
Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Thanks for the clarification, guys. Looks like my prostate is expanding every year. I'm in the process of moving to a new urologist and just got a copy of all my tests, biopsies, etc from the last doc. Two years ago they said it was 33 grams. Last year, 50 grams. Now it's 61 grams. I've had prostatitis off and on for years and years. Wonder if that tends to enlarge it.
Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Thanks for the note back, Southsider. I had been seeing a great urologist here in SoCal for over 20 years who decided to retire. He was pretty spot on and I always felt he was doing the right thing based on the current situation. Most of his advice I bounced off this forum and I think everyone here concurred with his ideas. Now that he's retired, I initially decided to see his office partner, a female urologist about 10 years his junior. She's got good qualifications but in all my visits, I've only seen her once. Her office relies heavily on nurse practitioners who are helpful but I don't feel I'm getting the best care. They also offer all sorts of woman's spa and beauty treatments as well which was the deal breaker for me. I'd rather have a pure urologist than someone who gave me the feeling they'd rather be selling something else. I've found a pretty seasoned guy and hope he fits the bill. First visit in a few weeks.

Posts.Title: Prostate size and volume calculations

Posts.Content: Thanks for the notes back on my post! My doctor's instructions said I could have a light breakfast the day of the biopsy. After reading what Jim215 put, it made me think that the enema is going to take care of cleaning me out so my guess is I won't have my morning constitutional. I can hold off on breakfast for awhile. I will have some coffee. Because of my prostatitis, the doctor has me off all alcohol and caffeine. for two weeks prior to the test to make sure there's the least amount of irritation to my prostate I guess. I do miss my caffeinated coffee and wine......
Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: Thanks for the notes back on my post! My doctor's instructions said I could have a light breakfast the day of the biopsy. I do miss my caffeinated coffee and wine......
Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: In preparation for my biopsy, my doctor told me that since it's going to be at 9:00 AM, to use the Fleet enema the night before. That struck me as odd since I normally have my constitutional after breakfast in the morning. Wouldn't it make more sense to have the enema after the constitutional and before the biopsy to make sure you're squeaky clean? Wonder what others experiences have been.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: In preparation for my biopsy, my doctor told me that since it's going to be at 9:00 AM, to use the Fleet enema the night before. That struck me as odd since I normally have my constitutional after breakfast in the morning. Wouldn't it make more sense to have the enema after the constitutional and before the biopsy to make sure you're squeaky clean? Wonder what others experiences have been.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Prep Question

Posts.Content: Hello Michael, Thanks much for the advice. I will make sure to talk to my URO about a PHI or at lease PSAFree test. Hadn't thought about the MRI though! Good idea. I live in southern California so I'm guessing they should have one in our area. It's hard to not jump to the next steps and have fears that I have PCa that must come out!
Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: Hello to all on this holiday week. Yesterday, I got a call from my urologist with the results of a Select MDx test they did as a result of my recent PSA test. The results were not good, higher risk than the doctor would like. My PSA was 4.3 in October and they also found a UTI which I took 28 days of antibiotics for. Since I've already had a biopsy in August, 2016 that was negative, they're asking me to get an MRI now. I'm guessing they will decide then if they want to biopsy or not. I'm scheduled to get another PSA test in February and a return visit to the urologist in March. Trying not to get worked up about things and hoping that waiting until March is not a bad thing. I've had bouts of prostatitis in the past and wonder if a biopsy is warranted here. I know over 4 is not good but my numbers don't seem that bad but the Select MDx seems to warrant further checking. I've posted in the forum before as Sandy09 but changed my login and this is my first post at Woodman. Can't quite get the hang of logins and password sometimes! Looking for any suggestions and/or advice as everying has been very helpful and encouraging in the past. My recent PSAs are below. 3.0 Dec 2014 3.8 Dec 2015 3.9 Jan 2016 4.7 Jul 2016 Free PSA 33% 4k Score 21% Biopsy Aug 2016 negative 3.5 Apr 2017 4.3 Oct 2017 UTI - Antibiotics 28 days 4.1 Dec 2017 - UTI gone
Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: Thanks, Rob. Appreciate the note back. Hadn't thought about the training a URO would need to perform an MRI guided biopsy. Good tip. Also, thanks for the computer, techsupport words!
Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: I've read many posts here about the PHI test and it does look like a pretty good test especially in my case. I've never requested a test from any of my doctors and I'll put that down to me. I realize I need to take control of my care but so often I take what they suggest as gospel and think 'what do I know about all this anyway? They're the experts, right?' I am on track to get an MRI probably after the first of the year and I'm lucky that my PPO will pick it up (all but 10%). I'm guessing the URO wants this to see if there's anything there or to be ready for a biopsy or both?
Posts.Title: Heading for a second biopsy maybe?

Posts.Content: Thanks a ton for your reply, Otago. Believe me, it is very helpful to me. Also thanks for taking the time to read my old posts all those years ago and yes, you're correct, I was overreacting then as well. I'm an expert over reactor. I drive my wife nuts. But folks like you and the others on this forum help me enormously to deal with this. Going to the doctor's office is not one of my favorite things. I've been seeing the same Urologist for many, many years and I've always found him to be pretty conservative and not willing to go overboard on things. When I started seeing him it was for prostatitis and BPH. I've come back usually on a yearly basis and he's always set the return appointment times for me based on what he thinks is sensible. I pretty much follow his lead. I'm encouraged that many of you on this forum feel his advice is sound as you guys have been there and your thoughts are invaluable to me. Not to mention putting my mind to rest about dumb things to worry about. The more I read about the prostate, I'm beginning to see and understand the notion of living with (and monitoring) prostate cancer. It's a concept that has always kept me up at night because I guess I've always thought it should just come out! Spending time on this forum has made me see things in a different light. It's made me feel much better. Thanks for that! Back in July of 2015, my PSA was 3.1. In December it was 3.8. At that time, my doctor said to come back in 6 months and do a free PSA test which came back at 4.7 and 33%. That's where I'm at now. About a week before my last test, I started to get some prostatitis symptoms again which are more noticable after the DRE. My doctor suggested the 4kscore test out of caution and basically echoed what you are saying. Don't panic! His reasoning is the same as yours, if the 4kscore test looks good, we'll just retest in 6 months. I will gather up all my PSA numbers and post them back. Appreciate the thoughs and suggestions. They do me alot of good - you have no ide.
Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: Thanks for the note back, Chuck, I do remember that a day before my last PSA test, I had that "feeling" of fullness in my perineum, kind of like sitting on a golf ball. That's my usual symptom, sometimes a lower back ache as well. The doctor did a DRE and mentioned if he found anything he'd do a biopsy right away. He didn't find anything, fortunately. He did then arrange for me to do a 4kscore test, next week, to see what my chances of aggressive cancer might be. From what I've read, that test does PSA, Free PSA and two other biomarkers of some sort. Depending on the results, he suggested we'd discuss a biopsy or if the results are good, see him again in 6 months. I haven't been tested for Prostatitis by this doc. He has diagnosed me with BPH but he told me my prostate doesn't feel enlarged. Does BPH enlarge your prostate?
Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: Thanks ASAdvocate for your response. My doctor seems to think the same as you. He doesn't want to just jump in a do a biopsy unless it's absolutely necessary. We discussed the 4k test which I will get next week. He said if it looks good, we'll just keep checking every 6 months and stay on top of it. It seems so unusual to me that one could "live" with Prostate Cancer without the urge to get it out. You're living proof! Thanks again for the helpful words.
Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: Hello to all. I'm 62 and regular viewer of the forum, albeit Prostate cancer free so far. I just visited my Uro doc yesterday to review my latest PSA readings. My PSA was 3.8, 6 months ago and now it's jumped to 4.7. He did a Free PSA test this time and it came back at 33%. He's told me this is good and I should be comforted by it. When he told me 4.7, however, I immediately thought that we should do a biopsy right away with the change since last time. He advised me not to jump into it so fast and that with my history of Prostatitis and BPH, the number could be related to that. He wants me to do a 4kscore test to see what the likelihood of me developing cancer is and then we'll sit and talk about what to do next, in about 3 weeks. I've been going to this doc for over 8 years and I do trust him and find his conservative approx makes sense in my sensible mind. He says he does lots of biopsies and assures me that if the 4kscore test comes back poorly, we'll arrange for me to have one. Otherwise he could suggest Active Surveillance. My gut tells me that if they find even the littlest bit of cancer I want it out! Am I overreacting to all this? Thanks for letting me get it off my chest!
Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Title: To biopsy or not

Posts.Content: Yesterday, I sat down with my uro doc and went over the 4kscore test he ordered. Found that I scored 21% which the doctor felt was worthy of a biopsy. I'm scheduled for one in two weeks. He thought that since my PSA was inching up and combined with the 4kscore he thought it the best course. I can't say I argue with him. I dug up some of my previous PSA tests and am including them here 6/14 3.1 12/14 3.0 12/15 3.8 7/16 4.7
